awd_titl_txt: Noncommutative Algebras and Related Categorical Structures
awd_abstract_narration:
Many models in the sciences and engineering lead to mathematical problems about solutions of equations in commuting variables. However, starting with quantum mechanics, a great number of models emerged that led to mathematical problems involving variables that no longer commute. Noncommutative Algebra is one of the areas of mathematics that studies those structures. The research projects that are funded by this award investigate the interrelations between the commutative and noncommutative settings, using a branch of geometry called Poisson geometry. Three other approaches are used to study the noncommutative setting:  a combinatorial approach based on intricate internal transformations of the objects, called cluster mutations;  an algebraic approach that investigates intrinsically defined structures called Calabi-Yau categories; and  a noncommutative geometric approach using quantum versions of symmetric spaces. The four approaches are simultaneously used to carry out a detailed study of the properties and symmetries of noncommutative objects. Further, the noncommutative objects are shown to exhibit various forms of rigidity. This is used to settle problems in algebra, geometry, combinators, and dynamical systems that were previously posed without any reference to the noncommutative setting. These research activities will be used as the foundation for the training of graduate and undergraduate students and for mentoring mathematics postdocs.

The research projects funded under this awaard investigate problems in noncommutative algebra, quantum symmetric spaces, and noncommutative projective algebraic geometry and the relations of these problems to Poisson geometry, combinatorics, triangulated categories, and integrable systems. On the one hand, the program aims at using methods from the latter areas to describe the structure and representations of quantum cluster algebras at roots of unity, the Drinfeld doubles of Nichols algebras, the algebras that appear in the theory of quantum symmetric pairs, and the algebras that describe noncommutative projective spaces. In the opposite direction, previously posed problems in the latter areas are converted to problems for noncommutative algebras and their representation categories, and are then resolved within that setting. One of the directions of this program is the construction of universal K-matrices on the symmetric subalgebras of the Drinfeld doubles of Nichols algebras, and using this to study the ring theoretic properties of Nichols algebras. Another direction aims at the classification of irreducible representations of Nichols algebras of diagonal type using Poisson orders and noncommutative discriminants. A third direction develops a general setting for the study of finite dimensional representations of quantum cluster algebras at root of unity using Poisson geometry and Cayley-Hamilton algebras. Three additional directions investigate the geometry of noncommutative projective spaces modeled by higher dimensional elliptic algebras, the structure of 2-Calabi-Yau categories via categorical C-vectors and dynamical systems, and the construction of integral quantum cluster algebra structures on the canonical forms of quantized coordinate rings of varieties in theory of Lie groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Summary of Outcomes: Many models in the sciences and engineering lead to mathematical problems about solutions of equations in commuting variables. At the same time, in many other settings, such as quantum mechanics, a large number of important models are phrased in terms of mathematical problems involving variables that no longer commute. Noncommutative Algebra is one of the areas of mathematics that studies those structures.

The research projects that were funded by this award investigated the interrelations between the commutative and noncommutative settings. They used methods from four branches of mathematics: Poisson geometry, noncommutative geometry, combinatorics and category theory. The four approaches were simultaneously used to carry out a detailed study of the properties and symmetries of noncommutative objects with a particular emphasis on the representation theory of the noncommutative objects. Furthermore, the noncommutative objects were shown to exhibit various forms of rigidity.

The PI advised PhD and undergraduate students, mentored postdocs, designed new graduate level courses, and organized two annual conference series.

Outcomes related to Intellectual Merit: Quantum cluster algebras at roots of unity form a vast class of noncommutative objects that include special subfamilies of objects that play a role in mathematical physics, topology, and algebra. The representation theory and geometry of this large class were were described in great detail.

Simultaneously, the projects funded by the proposal developed the representation theory of related quantum groups (Hopf algebras) by two complementary approaches via discriminants and support maps. In the former direction the projects developed a geometric framework for tackling the problem of describing all irreducible representations of quantum supergroups at roots of unity.

In a different direction, a comprehensive theory of noncommutative tensor triangular geometry was developed. It linked the very active areas of triangulated categories and enveloping algebras. For each monoidal triangulated category a rich invariant was defined, its noncommutative Balmer spectrum. The invariant was shown to detect important features of the underlying category. Theorems for its explicit reconstruction were obtained. 

The construction of quantum cluster structures on algebraic objects has attracted a lot of attention due to the application of the former structures towards the descriptions of the representations of the latter. One of the projects funded by the award settle the problem of construction of such structures on the quantum Schubert cells of all Kac-Moody groups.

Quantum symmetric spaces were explicitly described as star products on partial bosonizations. This determined their defining relations for all Kac-Moody algebras. Quantum K-matrices were constructed by a new general categorical tool of reflective centers of module categories, which can be applied to broad spectrum of algebraic and categorical situations.

Outcomes related to Broader Impacts: The research activities funded by this award were used as the foundation for training of graduate and undergraduate students and for mentoring mathematics postdocs. The PI graduated 3 PhD students and advised 3 other PhD students who are working towards their degrees at the moment. The PI developed new graduate level courses on the foundations of the research projects funded this award. He is also one of the coorganizers of two annual conferences: the Canada-Mexico-US Conference series on Representation Theory, Categorification and Noncommutative Algebra and the Maurice Auslander Distinguished Lectures and International Conference. Both conference series cover topics that are closely related to the projects funded by this award. 

Integral operators with the prolate spheroidal property are of great interest due to applications in signal processing and computer tomography. An infinite dimensional family of such operators was constructed from the points of Wilson's Adelic Grassmannian and its discrete counterparts. The construction is based on developing new tools from Noncommutative Algebra on Fourier algebras of bispectral functions in the complex holomorphic and discrete settings.
